docs.lead_paragraph: MOST parents worry about the costs of raising their children, but a recent boom in multiple births has introduced a new level of parental panic: financing babies in triplicate. The number of triplet births more than tripled between 1980 and 1994, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Some studies estimate that fertility treatments have caused 60 percent to 80 percent of the increase. In 1995, some 4,551 babies were born in sets of triplets, according to the center, and about 400 babies in sets of quadruplets or greater multiples.

headline.main: When Babies Arrive In Bunches, So Do the Bills

docs.abstract: Boom in multiple births is forcing many families to face new financial problems; parents comment on coping with high costs of raising multiple babies; photos (L)
docs.snippet: MOST parents worry about the costs of raising their children, but a recent boom in multiple births has introduced a new level of parental panic: financing babies in triplicate.    The number of triplet births more than tripled between 1980 and 1994,...

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN today, after years of rising unemployment, it isn't hard to see why Germany once won worldwide praise as a workers' paradise. Full-time employees are entitled to six weeks of paid vacation. They get comprehensive health insurance, including, every four years, three weeks of ''spa leave'' for recuperation at health resorts, if a doctor prescribes it. Unemployment and job-training benefits can easily last more than two years. Universities are free and good. And as in most of Europe, tough laws make it almost impossible to fire people.

headline.main: The World; The Jobless Are Snared In Europe's Safety Net

docs.abstract: Unemployment in Europe remains twice as high as in United States, and upcoming summit conference on joblessness is not expected to achieve much; Europe's laws and union contracts have enshrined so many job guarantees that system protects those who have jobs at expense of those who do not; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The recovery of repressed traumatic memories that, left unresolved, make people unhappy and impede their progress, is one of the most priceless gifts of psychotherapy (front page, Nov. 6). The reprehensible examples of patient manipulation and memory fabrication you reported result from insurance companies assigning most psychological services to cost-efficient medical doctors, pharmacologists and para-professionals whose hurried approaches to the intricate nature of repressed memory are comparable to performing brain surgery with a monkey wrench.

headline.main: Memory Therapy Is a Danger to Patients

docs.abstract: Letter from Daniel Coben says malpractice cases reported in Nov 6 article about 'memory' therapy lawsuitshould not result in broad denial of existence of repressed memories; says what is needed is re-examination of which professional is best qualified to make that determination on case-by-case basis (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S open enrollment time for many benefits plans, and a big question for families is this: Should they stay with their low-cost H.M.O. or switch to a managed-care plan with more freedom to choose a doctor or other professional, called a ''point-of-service'' feature? Point-of-service plans are the fastest-growing sector in health insurance. The plans are not without their benefits for patients, providers and insurers. But are they a good deal for everyone?

headline.main: Health Plans With Choice: Good Deals?

docs.abstract: Advice on choosing between health maintenance organizations and point-of-service plans, managed-care plans that offer more freedom to select doctor or other professional; some consumer advocates say point-of-service plans are worth added costs, although consumers can rack up high charges when using out-of-network doctors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the ''recovered memories'' that psychiatrists told Patricia Burgus she had were fantastical: that she cannibalized people, was raped by dozens of men, had sex with President John F. Kennedy, engaged in satanic rituals. When her years of therapy were over, she accused doctors of implanting false memories. Last week, she won a $10.6 million legal settlement, the largest in a series of similar cases. Over the last decade, recovered memories of abuse were more often the basis of suits and criminal charges against the alleged abusers. The swinging of the psychiatric pendulum now raises a slew of questions. Why do recovered memories have such a common thread of bizarre visions? If therapists don't suggest them, do they encourage patients to believe them? What is the role of hypnosis and drugs in therapy? Are any recovered memories of abuse or trauma true?

headline.main: November 2-8; She Recovered Memories, Then Millions in Damages

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate gave final approval today to the largest of the Federal spending bills for 1998, but Congress remained deadlocked on other contentious issues as supporters and opponents of expanded trade authority for the President maneuvered for advantage and votes. By a vote of 91 to 4, the Senate this afternoon passed the $277 billion spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education. The House passed the measure on Friday, 352 to 65.

headline.main: Major Spending Bill Passes Amid Jockeying on Trade

docs.abstract: Senate passes 91 to 4 $277 billion spending bill for Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education; White House chief of staff Erskine B Bowles and other senior Administration officials try to persuade recalcitrant House Democrats to accept some contentious provisions on 2000 census and other issues that Republicans want in return for supporting fast-track trade legislation; Senate confirms Pres Clinton's nomination of Nancy-Ann Min DeParle to be head of Federal Health Care Financing Administration; Senate passes bill that would ease adoptions of children who have been abused or abandoned by their parents, making children's safety, rather than family reunification, guiding principal in such cases; Bowles photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KATHERINE LAMPOS often feels the urge to go whitewater rafting in New Mexico or visit a national park. So she does, for a week or two. That's O.K. with her boss, because Ms. Lampos, 52 years old, doesn't have one. She's a self-employed ''professional temp,'' one of a growing number of people who work project by project rather than the classic 40-hour week. ''I may not get rich,'' says Ms. Lampos, who has worked 10 to 11 months each year since 1988, ''but I'm earning a living and I'm never bored. If I take a permanent position, I can't leave when I want to leave or take a day off when I want to. This is a life style that you can become accustomed to.''

headline.main: Temps, the New Wave in the Work Force

docs.abstract: Number of 'professional temps,' people who work project by project, is growing; temporary workers range from administrative support personnel to graphic designers, accountants, lawyers, marketing specialists and executives; industry has grown from $20.5 billion in 1991 to record $43.6 billion in 1996, and trend is expected to continue; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, black evokes sophistication and stylishness, and white is a fashion faux pas. But what if they sprain a wrist or break an arm or finger and suddenly need a splint? Now there is hope. At Hand Rehabilitation Services at 310 East 30th Street, Roxanne Perry, an occupational therapist, makes plastic splints in five colors: pink, light blue, royal blue, white -- and, yes, black. Although half her patients choose white, about 40 percent pick black.
docs.abstract: At Hand Rehabilitation Services in Manhattan, Roxanne Perry, occupational therapist, makes plastic hand splints in five colors; splints, available by doctor's prescription only, cost $100 to $150; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The greatest untold story of the mangy little election year of 1997 is (a) the Staten Island ballot initiative to recall Susan Molinari from CBS News; (b) Ruth Messinger's last-minute request for campaign tips from Betsy McCaughey Ross, or (c) the potent subliminal effect of Bob Dole's much-photographed, newly taut face on turning out the G.O.P. youth vote. The correct answer is (d), the triumph of pro-choice candidates in the Republican Party, which only a year ago stood on a platform calling for a constitutional ban on all abortions. Both Rudolph Giuliani, New York's re-elected Mayor, and Christine Todd Whitman, New Jersey's re-elected Governor, are unambiguous supporters of abortion rights. The third major G.O.P. victor on Tuesday -- James Gilmore, elected Governor in the far more conservative venue of Virginia -- is not, but even he ran commercials far to the left of his party's official stand. ''The Supreme Court has spoken,'' said the Gilmore ads. ''No one's going to ban abortions.''
docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column on Gov Christine Todd Whitman's narrow re-election victory in New Jersey and victory of other pro-choice Republicans; holds Republican Establishment minimizes victories that run counter to party wisdom that road to national victory requires strict fealty to religious right (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Laboring under a deadline for adjournment, the House tonight approved a $277 billion spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education that includes a deal to delay and restrict President Clinton's national educational-testing program. The legislation, the largest of the 13 Federal spending bills, passed on a vote of 352 to 65.

headline.main: House, in Passing Spending Bill, Limits and Delays Clinton's Testing Program

docs.abstract: House, 352-65, approves $277 billion spending bill for Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education that includes deal to delay and limit Pres Clinton's national educational-testing program; bill bars use of Federal money to buy health plans that pay for abortions; continue ban on use of human embryos in Federally financed research; ends use of Federal money for programs that distribute sterile needles to drug addicts; bars use of Federal money for teamsters election; House approves stopgap spending bill, third since 1998 fiscal year began Oct 1; approves bipartisan bill to spend $100 million to help create charter public schools, 367-57; Senate approves compromise Amtrak bill to release $2.3 billion for capital improvements and $3.4 billion for operating subsidies (M)
